title: Government and business face up to new realities
text:
Even after Bill Shorten’s attack on the big end of town helped Labor lose the election, junior minister Ben Morton last week put big business in its place. The Coalition government doesn’t represent corporate Australia, he told a business gathering. The Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister accused business of pandering to noisy elitist political activists rather than delivering on the aspirations of the “hard-working middle and aspirational Australians” who returned the government to power. As political editor Phillip Coorey exclusively foreshadowed last Saturday, Energy Minister Angus Taylor then reintroduced the Coalition’s “big stick” legislation to allow the government to break up integrated energy companies found to have rigged the market or gouged electricity consumers. Notwithstanding whimpers of protest from Liberal backbench dries, it started to look like an avalanche of new regulation promoted, ironically, by the assistant minister responsible for cutting red tape.

The business culture wars looked like escalating as the likes of Qantas boss Alan Joyce and BHP chief Andrew Mackenzie defended the role of business in various social causes and in combating climate change. The Millennials who turned out for Friday’s climate change strike are not the “quiet Australians” whom Scott Morrison and Mr Morton want to reward for returning the Coalition to government. Nor are the activist shareholder investors who are becoming the new capitalist owners of corporate Australia.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison. The Coalition and business have been mending bridges. Alex Ellinghausen

Yet, amid this culture war distraction, the Coalition and big business ended the week closer as the emerging Middle East oil crisis added to the US-China trade war, Brexit and Hong Kong to unsettle investor confidence. Pitchfork culture wars and big-stick threats will make it harder for business to put investors' risk capital at work to grow the economy.

By Tuesday’s meeting with the Business Council of Australia in Canberra, Mr Morton’s rhetoric had shifted more behind this reality. Large companies were “a vital part of our economy”, he said. What was good for business was “good for all Australians”. Mr Morton applauded the Business Council’s “Strong Australia” campaign in regional Australia, praised its push for company tax cuts and backed its chief executive, Jennifer Westacott, for “having both policy consistency and the courage of your convictions”. He highlighted a task force to reduce red tape, a push to get big infrastructure projects up and running sooner, and help for very small businesses to become first-time employers. Mr Morrison turned up to the Tuesday night dinner and worked the room. By Wednesday morning, even Labor leader Anthony Albanese acknowledged that business-bashing and Mr Shorten’s politics of redistribution would not aid the cause of reviving productivity.

By announcing an end to a decade of Labor-initiated budget deficits, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg this week helped lay down a foundation of confidence that the Coalition has finally got the nation’s finances in order without jacking up taxes. That provides the rare prospect of twin surpluses on the budget and balance of payments. If the budget surplus can be nailed down for the current financial year and beyond, then Mr Frydenberg could be placed to announce a well-crafted investment allowance in the May budget as a second-best alternative to a generalised company tax cut. This week’s numbers show that while consumer spending remains soft, the labour market continues to generate solid job growth. Yet, as more Australians enter the job hunt, the unemployment rate edged up to 5.3 per cent – diverging from the Reserve Bank’s new target of 4.5 per cent. Financial markets responded by pricing in a 70 per cent chance that the Reserve Bank will cut its official cash rate below 1 per cent at its October 1 meeting. Yet this will mostly squeeze bank margins, make bank lenders more risk averse and penalise the retiree savers who helped return the Coalition to office. It will only go to prove that the scope for demand-side stimulus has been all but exhausted and that the only alternative way to enrich Mr Morrison’s quiet Australians is a burst of supply-side reforms that will encourage business to invest.
description: The Coalition and business ended the week closer amid all the culture war distractions.
